Award.AwardTitle: Assessing the role of methanogens in driving Earth's oxygenation using Nickle isotopes
Award.AbstractNarration:
The first substantial and long-lasting accumulation of oxygen in the atmosphere and surface waters of the oceans ~2.4 billion years ago was arguably one of the three most important turning points in the history of life, but exactly why and how this transformation took place remains poorly understood. One phenomenon that likely drove or at least stabilized the transition to a more oxidizing state was collapse of methanogens, a dominant form of life throughout much of the Archean Eon that sustained global anoxia through production of abundant methane. The objective of this project is to test the recent hypothesis of Konhauser et al. (2009; Nature 458, 750), who attributed the decline of methanogens to a shortage of nickel, an essential trace nutrient for these organisms. These authors argued that biogenic methane production might have waned well before the rise of oxygen, because oceanic Ni concentrations decreased substantially between 2.7 and 2.5 Ga.

The recent discovery that modern methanogens strongly fractionate stable isotopes of Ni suggests that Ni limitation of methanogens may have left an isotopic fingerprint in the sedimentary record. The aim of this study is to analyze Ni isotope compositions of the same samples in which Konhauser et al. documented the Ni concentration decline, to see if an isotopic shift reflecting the onset of Ni limitation of methanogens is evident. Samples will be extracted from the hematite-rich layers of banded iron formations by microdrill, and isotopic compositions will be measured by MC-ICP-MS. Investigator will focus in particular on relationships between Ni concentrations and Ni isotopes for samples with ages between 2.8 and 2.3 billion years, the interval over which methanogens may or may not have assimilated increasingly large proportions of available dissolved Ni in seawater.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our original goal was to determine whether a dramatic decline in the concentration of nickel in the oceans between 2.7 and 2.4 billion years ago played a role in the Great Oxidation Event, when the Earth transitioned from an anoxic planet to a slightly oxidized one 2.4 billion years ago. This event changed the course of evolution and eventually made complex life possible. For this transition to have occurred, the production of methane gas by organisms called methanogens must have plummeted. Because methanogens require nickel as a critical nutrient, the documented decrease in Ni concentrations may have been the cause of their demise.

We analyzed nickel isotopes in banded iron formation samples of different ages, expecting to see a shift in values if nickel availability for methanogens became limited. We did find a shift beginning at 2.7 billion years ago, from a very tight range of values before 2.7 billion years ago to an enormous range of both high and low values from 2.7 billion years ago forward. After doing some calculations, we are now certain that this shift was not directly driven by methanogen activity, but rather by larger-scale Earth processes that irreversibly changed the sources and sinks of nickel to the oceans. We are preparing a manuscript on these results for submission to either Geochimica et Cosmochimica Acta or Earth and Planetary Science Letters.

We moved beyond the original scope of the proposal to analyze nickel isotopes in glacial composites of different ages, to learn which larger-scale Earth processes contributed to that fundamental change in marine nickel cycling. Our results showed that, before 2.7 billion years ago, a principal flux of nickel to the oceans was from anoxic weathering of nickel from silicate minerals in the continental crust, namely from olivine. After 2.7 billion years ago, however, as the continental crust evolved to be less rich in olivine, the nickel concentration in the bulk crust declined. The nickel flux to the ocean also waned, and thus availability of nickel to methanogens, who were keeping the planet warm and anoxic, also decreased. Thus, the stage was set for oxygenation of the Earth’s surface, as the reducing gas methane became less abundant, and also for Earth’s first significant ice ages, because methane was the primary greenhouse gas in the first half of Earth history. Complete and permanent freezing of the planet was avoided, however, because even though the whole continental crust had lower nickel contents, a new weathering reaction turned on to dissolve what nickel was there and carry it to the oceans. This was weathering of Ni from sulfide minerals, which had previously not weathered much at all in the anoxic surface conditions. Our models of our measured isotope compositions and nickel fluxes show that the proportion of Ni coming from sulfide minerals likely came to dominate the flux from continents to oceans. Our results and model were published in Nature Geoscience in 2019.

In the last stage of the project, after the PI moved to a new university, we began to explore the nickel isotope composition of very young carbonate rocks precipitated from seawater, which no one had previously attempted. The objective was to lay groundwork for being able to interpret nickel isotope signatures in ancient carbonate rocks, by learning how Ni isotopes fractionate when carbonate minerals first precipitate from seawater. Our first measurements show a small fractionation, favoring incorporation of lighter Ni isotopes into calcite (d60Ni = 1.1‰). This part of the project will continue into 2021, and we will eventually publish our results when we can understand fractionation between seawater and primary calcite, primary aragonite, and aragonite that has converted into calcite during early burial and diagenesis.

A postdoc, a PhD student, and an undergraduate were involved in the research and publications as part of their training. The PI and students also staged some hands-on education outreach presentations at university science outreach events (Indiana University Science Fest) and at a local children’s science museum event (WonderLab, Bloomington, Indiana), 2015-2018.
